thread.title: Last ditch attempt to put a block on Brexit in the House of Commons
thread.title_full: Last ditch attempt to put a block on Brexit in the House of Commons

author: Jonathan Walker
title: Last ditch attempt to put a block on Brexit in the House of Commons
text:
Last ditch attempt to put a block on Brexit in the House of Commons Brexit Bill likely to be approved after Labour leadership urges MPs to back it Share EU and Union flags (Photo: PA)   
MPs are to hold an historic vote on whether to allow Brexit to go ahead after the SNP, Liberal Democrats and rebel Labour backbenchers launched attempts to block the legislation. 
But laws allowing Prime Minister Theresa May to trigger Brexit appeared certain to be approved, after the Labour leadership urged the party’s MPs to back them. 
Parliament has begun debating the European Union (Notification of Withdrawal) Bill, which allows Mrs May to invoke Article 50, the formal mechanism for leaving the EU. 
A vote on the “second reading” of the Bill will be held on Wednesday February 1. If it is approved, there will be further discussion next week in which MPs can attempt to make changes to the legislation. 
Lib Dems, the SNP and a small group of Labour backbenchers, including former leadership candidate Owen Smith, have backed an attempt to stop the Bill. 
But Labour Shadow Brexit Secretary Sir Keir Starmer said his party believed Brexit should go ahead. A European Union flag in front of Big Ben (Photo: Daniel Leal-Olivas/PA Wire) 
He told the House of Commons that he campaigned passionately for Remain in last year’s referendum. But he said: “As democrats our party has to accept the result and it follows that the Prime Minister should not be blocked from starting the Article 50.” 
With the support of both the Conservative and Labour leadership there is very little prospect of the legislation being blocked. 
Sir Keir also backed calls for the North East to be consulted about the Brexit process. 
He was responding to comments from Newcastle North MP Catherine McKinnell , who said she wanted to know what discussions the Government has had with the North East about the impact of leaving the single market, “given that 58% of our exports go to the EU.” 
Ministers were forced to bring forward legislation after the Supreme Court ruled Parliament’s approval is needed before the two-year formal Brexit withdrawal process can begin. 
The Government wants this to start before the end of March. Read More North East firms say EU trading still vitally important 
Opening the debate, Brexit Secretary David Davis, a supporter of leaving the EU, said: “At the core of this Bill lies a very simple question - do we trust the people or not?” 
Most MPs who supported remaining in the European Union appear to be planning to vote to trigger Article 50.
